text: What's the fastest way to write/read/clear data with a time series in python? I've got a script that scrapes data every few seconds and stores it in a mysql database. It deletes data more than x seconds old so there's usually only 5 records of 2 fields. One is the scrape time the other is the data, a 20 digit number. Speed is important and using mysql seems OTT

text: Considering speed is important and the data size is tiny, yes, I wouldn't look to move this out to a dedicated k/v store until you start hitting the limitations of python or need multi process support etc. Easy to get lost and waste a lot of time on over engineering stuff like this (imho)

text: Folks, quick question please..First time I ran a live strategy (Whoop!)...but placed a bet deliberately low at 1.03..If I stop the program to edit the code and then restart it, does it somehow keep a live connection (ie am I in danger of  having too many connections if I stop and start it regularly? Thanks

text:
It seems an odd setup but my knowledge of python isn't strong enough for me to be confident. 

Script 1 (the one referred to above) scrapes data to the mysql database. 

Script 2 harvests links from emails using imap_tools and when a link is scraped calls Script 3 using os.system(f'start "window title" cmd /k "python scrape.py (link) && exit"').

Script 3 then uses the data in mysql to scrape part of these sites.

elements.text:

Script 2 harvests links from emails using imap_tools and when a link is scraped calls Script 3 using os.system(f'start "window title" cmd /k "python scrape.py (link) && exit"').

Script 3 then uses the data in mysql to scrape part of these sites.

text: Potentially yes, but I doubt you will reach it unless you make a lot of restarts, we try and close the connections gracefully but betfair doesn’t always honour this, tbh I think we could improve this part of the code

elements.text: It does seem really cool/interesting though so looking forward to getting comfortable with these trees!

text: I have generally accepted that if you have, say, more than 10 features then you might as well consider your XGBoost model a black box and it becomes quite difficult to interpret. I'd lump it in with neural nets with multiple hidden layers etc. Idk if anyone else here spends time interpreting their trees but IMO if it does well out of sample and you've been clean with your modelling approach then you are probably good to go. With that being said, the sklearn api for XGBoost exposes "feature importances" - I'd definitely analyse these and ensure they somewhat make sense.

elements.text: I have generally accepted that if you have, say, more than 10 features then you might as well consider your XGBoost model a black box and it becomes quite difficult to interpret. I'd lump it in with neural nets with multiple hidden layers etc. Idk if anyone else here spends time interpreting their trees but IMO if it does well out of sample and you've been clean with your modelling approach then you are probably good to go. With that being said, the sklearn api for XGBoost exposes "feature importances" - I'd definitely analyse these and ensure they somewhat make sense.

text: Gotcha, that all makes sense thanks Dave! For me, I'm a bit worked up on just wrapping my head around what is going on before trusting the more black-boxiness of it. I think it's something of my "old man on his porch who took econometrics" training but I really want to have some idea of how it works and what's going on before I go with the heavier-handed feature selection algos and the data splitting into testing and training etc.

elements.text: Gotcha, that all makes sense thanks Dave! For me, I'm a bit worked up on just wrapping my head around what is going on before trusting the more black-boxiness of it. I think it's something of my "old man on his porch who took econometrics" training but I really want to have some idea of how it works and what's going on before I go with the heavier-handed feature selection algos and the data splitting into testing and training etc.

text: Also just out of general curiosity, too, I feel like if I'm even considering relying on it in any meaningful way, I want to at least be able to layman explain how it works, and open up trees and trace them through and say what their predictions would be etc.

elements.text: Also just out of general curiosity, too, I feel like if I'm even considering relying on it in any meaningful way, I want to at least be able to layman explain how it works, and open up trees and trace them through and say what their predictions would be etc.

text:
Most tutorials are maybe more "practical" or something, and they seem to not worry too much about opening a tree, looking at it, and saying what it means. It makes sense on some level that tutorials are very focused on "okay, so you should set up your out of sample and in sample, now let's run that, now let's look at how it works, set some parameters in a decent way, how was our fit? Oh it's pretty good!" which I of course am interested in too, but I'm also interested in like... "given this 8-leaf relatively simple tree, I should be able to manually calculate a few data points myself, right?

I definitely get that the best trees with 10 features like you say will get above the point where that's practical, but I'm just starting by feeding 3 features and 1600 data points and trying to understand like "what exactly is happening here?" which maybe is a dumb step, but I feel like tutorials aren't messing with at all.

elements.text:

text: My working theory now is there is some intercept term that isn't in my "tree" graph that R makes, or that I didn't notice in there. Because when I tell it to actually predict values, plenty are positive, even though every leaf is negative, and I think I'm at least right about the basic idea that you would go through each tree, find the value, and sum them together.

elements.text: My working theory now is there is some intercept term that isn't in my "tree" graph that R makes, or that I didn't notice in there. Because when I tell it to actually predict values, plenty are positive, even though every leaf is negative, and I think I'm at least right about the basic idea that you would go through each tree, find the value, and sum them together.

text: The "right" thing to do is to interpret your models of course and disect them, but unfortunately XGBoost doesn't make it easy. If you are keen on interpretable tree models, maybe look at Random Forest? Generally given the same set of features, a RF model and a XGB model will have similar predictive ability. It is quite easy to plot trees from RF though and visualize them with graphviz. Maybe it could be a good first step before moving onto xgb

text: For what it's worth, I did just run predictions, and then spot checked two points, and it does seem to me like the final prediction just has a constant/intercept term added of .5. Just in case others run into similar problems or get curious about how these things work. So, my model has all these negative leaf values, but the predictions are ultimately all of those + .5

text: I'm still digging in, but on the surface, it seems so cool/crazy that with 2 continuous features that are predicting another very similar continuous feature, and 1611 data points, that we can get way lower RMSE with a simple tree that basically is like "look, I'm gonna divy y'all up into 4 groups based on less-than statements and call it a day" instead of assigning continuous weights to the two variables. 5 distinct groups outperforming linear weighting seems so counter-inutitive and interesting to me. Edit: It looks to me like RMSE is the same now between basic linear and the super super simple tree.
